raw_text:
Henin-Hardenne beaten on comeback
 
 Justine Henin-Hardenne lost to Elena Dementieva in a comeback exhibition match in Belgium on Sunday for her second defeat in two days.
 
 And the Belgian, who has slipped to eight in the world after struggling with a virus, faces a tough Australian Open title defence next month. "I will be heading to Australia with a lot of question marks over me, I know that," she said. "But I think there'll be less pressure than last time even if I am champion." Henin-Hardenne was speaking after a 6-2 5-7 6-2 loss to world number six Dementieva in Charleroi, Belgium, on Sunday. The previous day, the Olympic champion went down 6-2 7-5 to France's Nathalie Dechy.
 
 "I have to be positive, I still have a few weeks," she said. "My body has to get accustomed again to the stress, the rhythm." Henin-Hardenne slid down the world rankings in the second half of 2004 after contracting the illness in April. After an initial lay-off, she was forced off the circuit for a second time after being knocked out of the French Open in the second round. A comeback at the US Open after a three-month absence ended when she crashed out at the fourth-round stage. But despite her problems, she still won five of the nine official tournaments she entered in 2004 and won Olympic gold in Athens, an achievement which saw her named Belgian sportswoman of the year on Friday. "Physically, it's obvious that I hit rock bottom," said the 22-year-old, who will make her comeback in the Sydney International from 10-16 January. "Since April, with the exception of the Olympics, I have not done much. "All the successes I had prior to that were mainly due to the work I put in on building up my fitness. "Now it's time to get back to putting in 200% effort and I think I am capable of doing that."
llama3.2:1b: Justine Henin-Hardenne lost to Elena Dementieva in a comeback exhibition match in Belgium, marking her second defeat in two days after slipping eight spots in the world rankings. She faces a tough Australian Open title defence next month, despite struggling with illness and returning slowly from a virus.
llama3.2:3b: Justine Henin-Hardenne lost two exhibition matches, a comeback exhibition match in Belgium and one in France, due to illness. She faces a tough Australian Open title defence next month, despite feeling under pressure. Henin-Hardenne has slid down the world rankings and feels she has hit rock bottom since contracting an illness in April 2004.
gemma2:2b: Justine Henin-Hardenne lost exhibition matches to Elena Dementieva and Nathalie Dechy, falling from world ranking after battling illness. She faces a tough Australian Open title defense and admitted she will need time to adjust physically. Despite these setbacks, she remains optimistic about her comeback in the Sydney International starting January 10th.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Henin-Hardenne won her second match in two days, beating Elena Dementieva with a comeback victory at the Charleroi tournament. She will face Australia's Johanna Konta on the world rankings in January, where she hopes to regain her Olympic gold medal after missing out on the 2018 Olympics due to an illness.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Justine Henin-Hardenne suffered a comeback defeat at the 2015 Australian Open exhibition match, facing Elena Dementieva for her second straight loss following a virus. She acknowledged she faces increased pressure compared to previous years heading into next month's tournament despite ongoing health concerns. The Belgian player noted that while recovery is possible with "a few weeks" of preparation ahead and physical adjustment needed, it remains uncertain how she will perform after a recent decline in ranking due to illness.
qwen2.5:3b: Justine Henin-Hardenne lost a comeback exhibition match against Elena Dementieva, her second loss in two days. Facing an Australian Open title defense next month after slipping to world No. 8 due to a virus, she plans to regain fitness but acknowledges increased pressure this time around despite winning Olympic gold and five of nine tournaments in 2004.

Henin-Hardenne lost 6-2 5-7 6-2 to Dementieva in Belgium, her second consecutive defeat since an illness blocked her path. She expressed concerns about facing a tough title defense next month at the Australian Open and shared that she'll be returning with some doubts but expects less pressure than last time after championing herself to a loss before.
tinyllama:1.1b: After slipping to an Australian Open title defeat, Justine Henin-Hardenne admitted she will face a difficult task as she seeks to regain her world ranking. The Belgian has lost on both occasions, and faces another challenge next month in the Australian Open, where she was defeated by Demetiévá earlier this year. The World No. 8 said her body still needs to get accustomed to the stress of competing again after a lengthy injury layoff that saw her miss three months of tournaments. Despite her struggles and setbacks, Henin-Hardenne has remained positive and committed to getting back on track in 2005.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Henin-Hardenne, world number six, lost her second match in two days against Elena Dementieva in a comeback exhibition match on Sunday. The Belgian tennis player has been struggling with illness and was forced to pull out of the French Open after suffering a defeat in the second round. Henin-Hardenne, 22 years old, will now begin her preparations for the Sydney International, where she plans to make her comeback, starting on January 10th.
